cards.back: A learning technique that uses increasing intervals between reviews to optimize long-term retention. Based on the forgetting curve research by Ebbinghaus.

cards.text: The FSRS algorithm tracks three variables: {{stability}}, {{difficulty}}, and {{retrievability}}.
{{Stability}} measures how slowly you forget - the higher it is, the longer until your next review.
{{Retrievability}} is the probability of successfully recalling a card at any given moment.

cards.definition: The idea that flashcards should test one simple fact each - simpler cards are easier to remember

cards.front: Why should you avoid flashcards that ask for lists?
cards.back: Lists are hard to remember because you have to recall multiple items in order. Better to break each item into its own card with context.

cards.text: Cloze deletion cards use {{blanks}} that you fill in, which is more effective than simple Q&A for many facts.

cards.definition: I love, you love, he/she loves (present active indicative of amare)
The branch of philosophy concerned with knowledge - what we can know and how we know it

cards.front: What is the time complexity of binary search?
cards.back: O(log n) - each step halves the search space

cards.text: {{Price elasticity of demand}} measures how much quantity demanded changes in response to a price change: %ΔQd / %ΔP.

cards.front: What does it mean when demand is 'elastic' (|E| > 1)?
cards.back: Quantity demanded changes more than proportionally to price. A 1% price increase causes >1% drop in quantity. Total revenue falls when price rises.

cards.text: The {{midpoint method}} for elasticity uses the average of start and end values as the base, giving the same elasticity regardless of direction.

cards.definition: Measures how quantity demanded of good A changes when the price of good B changes. Positive = substitutes, negative = complements.

cards.text: {{Consumer surplus}} is the area below the demand curve and above the market price - it represents the benefit buyers get from paying less than their maximum willingness to pay.
{{Deadweight loss}} is the reduction in total surplus that results from a market distortion like a tax, price control, or monopoly.

cards.front: Why does a monopolist produce where MR = MC rather than where P = MC?
cards.back: The monopolist faces a downward-sloping demand curve, so selling one more unit requires lowering the price on ALL units. MR < P because of this price effect. Producing where P = MC would mean MR < MC on the last unit - a loss.

cards.definition: Achieved when P = MC; resources go to their highest-valued uses and total surplus is maximized

cards.text: A {{Pigouvian tax}} corrects a negative externality by taxing the activity equal to the marginal external cost, making private cost equal social cost.

cards.definition: If property rights are well-defined and transaction costs are zero, private bargaining will reach an efficient outcome regardless of initial allocation

cards.front: What are the four conditions for perfect competition?
cards.back: 1) Many buyers and sellers (no market power), 2) Homogeneous products, 3) Free entry and exit, 4) Perfect information

cards.text: In the long run, firms in perfect competition earn {{zero economic profit}} because positive profits attract entry until P = ATC.

cards.definition: The rate at which a consumer is willing to trade one good for another while maintaining the same utility; equals the slope of the indifference curve

cards.text: At the optimal consumption bundle, {{MRS = price ratio}} (Px/Py), meaning the rate you're willing to trade equals the rate the market allows.
GDP can be calculated three ways: {{expenditure}} (C+I+G+NX), {{income}} (wages+rent+interest+profit), and {{production}} (sum of value added).

cards.front: What's the difference between real and nominal GDP?
cards.back: Nominal GDP uses current prices; real GDP uses constant base-year prices. Real GDP removes inflation to show actual output changes. Real = Nominal / Price Level × 100.

cards.definition: (Nominal GDP / Real GDP) × 100; measures the price level of all domestically produced goods, unlike CPI which measures a fixed consumer basket

cards.text: The three types of unemployment are {{frictional}} (job search), {{structural}} (skills mismatch), and {{cyclical}} (due to recessions).
The {{natural rate of unemployment}} is frictional + structural unemployment - the rate when the economy is at potential output with no cyclical unemployment.

cards.front: What are the three main tools of monetary policy?
cards.back: 1) Open market operations (buying/selling government bonds), 2) Discount rate (rate charged to banks borrowing from central bank), 3) Reserve requirements (fraction of deposits banks must hold)

cards.text: The {{money multiplier}} is 1/reserve ratio - it shows how much the money supply can expand from an initial deposit through fractional reserve banking.

cards.definition: When government borrowing raises interest rates, reducing private investment; limits the effectiveness of fiscal stimulus

cards.text: The {{Phillips curve}} shows an inverse relationship between unemployment and inflation in the short run - lower unemployment comes with higher inflation.

cards.front: Why is the long-run Phillips curve vertical?
cards.back: In the long run, expected inflation adjusts to actual inflation. Any unemployment below the natural rate causes accelerating inflation as expectations keep rising. The economy returns to the natural rate regardless of inflation level.

cards.definition: Simultaneous high inflation and high unemployment, typically caused by a negative supply shock; contradicts simple Phillips curve trade-off

cards.text: {{Okun's Law}} states that for every 1% unemployment rises above the natural rate, GDP falls about 2% below potential.

cards.definition: A strategy profile where no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy, given what others are doing

cards.front: Why is the Prisoner's Dilemma outcome inefficient?
cards.back: Both players defect (Nash equilibrium) even though mutual cooperation gives higher payoffs to both. Individual rationality leads to collective irrationality because each player's dominant strategy is to defect.

cards.definition: A strategy that gives a higher payoff than any alternative regardless of what other players do

cards.text: In a {{repeated game}}, cooperation can be sustained because players can punish defection in future rounds, unlike one-shot games.

cards.definition: Pre-contract information asymmetry where the uninformed party gets stuck with bad deals (e.g., only sick people buy insurance, only lemons get sold)
Post-contract behavior change because one party bears less risk; the insured take more risks, employees shirk when unmonitored

cards.front: What's the difference between adverse selection and moral hazard?
cards.back: Timing: Adverse selection is hidden information BEFORE a transaction (who you're dealing with). Moral hazard is hidden action AFTER a transaction (what they do once the deal is made).

cards.definition: When the informed party takes costly action to credibly reveal their type (e.g., education signals ability, warranties signal quality)
When the uninformed party designs a menu of options to make the informed party reveal their type through self-selection
When one party (principal) delegates to another (agent) whose interests differ; the principal can't perfectly monitor the agent's effort
Losses loom larger than gains - people feel a loss about 2x as strongly as an equivalent gain, leading to risk-aversion for gains but risk-seeking to avoid losses
People discount the near future more steeply than the far future, leading to time-inconsistent preferences (preferring $100 today over $110 tomorrow, but $110 in 31 days over $100 in 30 days)
Initial information disproportionately influences judgment even when irrelevant; people adjust insufficiently from the anchor

cards.text: {{Nudges}} are choice architecture interventions that steer behavior while preserving freedom of choice, like making good options the default.

cards.definition: People value things more once they own them; willingness to accept (WTA) exceeds willingness to pay (WTP) for the same item

cards.front: What's the difference between absolute and comparative advantage?
cards.back: Absolute advantage: producing more output with the same inputs. Comparative advantage: lower opportunity cost. Trade is based on comparative advantage - even if one country is better at everything, both gain by specializing in their lowest opportunity cost good.

cards.text: The {{terms of trade}} must fall between the two countries' opportunity costs for both to gain from trade.

cards.definition: An allocation where no one can be made better off without making someone else worse off; all gains from trade have been exhausted

cards.text: The {{First Welfare Theorem}} states that competitive equilibrium is Pareto efficient (under standard assumptions).
The {{Second Welfare Theorem}} states that any Pareto efficient allocation can be achieved as a competitive equilibrium with appropriate lump-sum transfers.

cards.definition: No voting system can satisfy all fairness criteria (transitivity, unanimity, independence of irrelevant alternatives, non-dictatorship) simultaneously
